n3xyT-7blRF8SkG26ApnHw.review_text: My wife and I and one of her friends were killing some time in the Wharf District waiting for our Vallejo Ferry ride back home. As we peered across the street from the Boudin Sourdough bread store we saw a cool looking bar and decided to give it a try. We found out this lounge had just been renovated and re-opened only about a week earlier so our timing couldn't have been better. The place is 100% upscale with everything clean and new throughout. It reminded us of the kind of place Frank Sinatra or Dean Martin would hang out at. They had a great selection of beers and a full bar with anything you'd possibly ever want or need. We picked a good time to be there (2:30 p.m.) because the manager was demonstrating the finer art of how to make a Lemon Drop and an Old Fashion which we graciously accepted (and gave a great tip for later). The bar was awesome and the place broadcasts a Wi-Fi signal and even has strategically placed power outlets all down the underside of the bar. They have a live band every night and have great drink prices too. After the fact, I stumbled across their web site: golddustloungesf.com I will most definitely make a return trip on my next time down to Fisherman's Wharf and would highly recommend this place!

xDqGPRY2nTRGWvuDH85mgA.review_text: I lived for a time on Pine at Taylor Street, and the Gold Dust was an ancient touristy dive bar on Powell from my time there. I went there seldomly when I lived near it, because it was always crowded. I would have spent a lot of time there if it had been larger or less crowded - it was my kind of place.  Now I live on a sailboat at Pier 39. The entire area is a tourist wasteland - toxic fish and chips made from breaded seafood slurry and overpriced t-shirt vendors anchored by the Academy of Art and the MUNI Yard. When they first started making noises about moving the Gold Dust to Fisherman's Wharf, I was dubious. The spot was good, but I couldn't see it.   Now that the Gold Dust is opened, I've been a few times and I have to say this - it totally works down here. As a matter of fact, it's one of the coolest venues on Fisherman's Wharf. To be fair, that bar is pretty low - there is nothing very memorable food or entertainment wise on Jefferson Street. That's why it's got 5 stars - it stands out as a gem on the Wharf.   My own complaints are personal and nostalgia related. The ADA rips the soul and charm out of a place. I loved the cramped old bar, but this one is big enough for powered wheelchairs to tool around in - even if the band needs them! The house band is still there and does indeed know just about every song in the world. The bathrooms are spacious and again, ADA compliant. Even behind the bar is... ADA compliant. It's not unwelcome, it's just unexpected when placed against my memories of the old Gold Dust.   So far all the employees have been pretty awesome to me as well, which is good because I can get really drunk and tear a place apart. They can handle drunks too though - I was there on Super Bowl Sunday and saw a lot of crying into multiple beers, which the staff handled with aplomb. As a reminder to myself, I have to tip them more.   And now comes that awkward part where I tell you to stay away. This is my new favorite place. But I don't have to do that, because the mere thought of going into Fisherman's Wharf terrifies you, non-tourist San Franciscan. Stop by occasionally, about as often as you did with the old one on Powell - it's not going anywhere. The  place may be way bigger but it's always got a crowd every time I've been in there.

Il7dIoxE5K0emDs9dR7zIQ.review_text: This place was cool. I wouldn't have expected it to be so aesthetically pleasing as I passed by the outside. All gold interior & a long bar. There was a live DJ this night and my friends and I were able to get a table at 10pm. Not a crowded spot for Saturday night but around 11 it finally started to fill up. Overall, nice spot to grab a drink with friends.

8g5gGo9XGY5A4D0Eu-_67Q.review_text: I was just here on a Thursday night. Kind of empty. I really loved the old time furniture and atmosphere.   Biggest drawback here is that the only food is pre-made and pulled from a cooler behind the bar. I had a turkey sandwich and was pleased that they use real turkey breast and not processed deli meat, but the sandwich was still average pre-packaged at best. I also had their Key Lime Margarita based on several positive reviews, was pretty good but not something I would brag about. Female bartender was very friendly and made this a very nice experience.  The only thing here that was fantastic was the piano player in the corner. He really made the place stand out as something unique and classy.   Overall, the decor is nice and I love the piano, but the lack of an open kitchen and the roughness of some of the bartenders making this a place I am unlikely to visit again.

SIi_wQ9PEYvUfRRGo72Bkg.review_text: We stumbled in here for a quick $3.50 Key Lime margarita advertised on the big sign sitting on the sidewalk while we were exploring Fisherman's Wharf.  I had no idea we were walking into such a piece of San Francisco history.  Or, maybe I am a sucker for the story.  It sounds like from the bartender the Gold Dust is an old landmark, that was evicted from its old space, and now resides on Fisherman's Wharf.  They recreated the feel of the old bar, and it really does feel like you're stepping back in time.  Velvet everywhere, bartender in an old school tux vest, and painted ceilings.  They use their own special margartia mix - Lefty O'Douls - and it's delicious.  They also have other Lefty mixes, like Bloody Marys. The key lime margarita actually tasted just like key lime.. yum.  And you cannot beat the happy hour price - relaxed atmosphere, good drinks, friendly bartender.  Mandatory stop on the Fisherman's Wharf stroll, and a great escape from the crowds.

DTB3kUme6_vRQDw00ZTSVQ.review_text: I walked past this place several times and finally stop right before heading out. This place is cool! Décor and the bartender were great. Cant beat the prices on the special drinks. This will be my first stop next time we come visit! two thumbs up!

MqfbqGJHWJF-0aKWf_V_5g.review_text: Relaxing place to chill and have a drink. Not the cheapest, but fun to hear the live jazz music.

HXwc6YOOq6hcZl0ovFeHiQ.review_text: This place is awesome! It has a fantastic location smack dab in the middle of Fisherman's Wharf Despite the touristy location, they have great drink prices here and the Happy Hour goes from 8am-8pm! The setting is a beautiful, classic, old place and it's being restored to it's original condition. There are frescoes on the ceiling, lots of velvet and suede on the walls and booths, along with awesome chandeliers. The bartenders are friendly and helpful. This is a pretty cool place to hang.

KUohiVbxXpEQlULLiGHvmw.review_text: Came here with my cousin and her bf. I've always passed by but never came in. Amazingly I was greeted by "Dean Martin"... Funny stuff :)  We came in during their happy hour special.  The staff were friendly with a hint of sarcasm, totally hilarious!!   We were taking pictures and my phone was about to die. The bartender heard me bickering about my phone dying and told me about the power strip under the bar. SAY WHAT!! How convenient! Luckily I had my cord to charge up my phone :)  Thanks gold-dust!

6Uch0mZfzps8CAhXyYG39Q.review_text: Gold Dust Lounge closed- very sad Gold Dust Lounge reopened in the Wharf - very happy Bartender ( tall asian young male | boy band hairdo | tight ass pants | pouty "I do what I want attitude" ) from the Fast and the Furious -very sad

G0aGbAlw32t7QE25EeWe_Q.review_text: Went there on a Saturday night...all I can say is HORRIBLE. We followed the bar from its original location, and apparently it lost its way. The bartenders were taking shots behind the bar, and never in the longest 15 minutes of my life did anyone acknowledge  us. It's a shame to.see an iconic establishment let itself go. Not to mention, horribly dirty. Never again.

JDBbNoWEYwezggWSV6aQ8A.review_text: Interesting place. It's huge and crowded. Drinks are cheap. Don't know if they do food.

js4wjUqfNu4xJBu27KZKhg.review_text: The 4th star is for bringing something of a period San Francisco establishment to a  part of the City woefully short of anything of quality or character.  Sadly, the cherub mural on the ceiling of the original joint did not make the transition, so the place isn't quite tied together as well as the old place was, by the artwork---and the ceilings are lower, but other than that the vibe has more or less traveled over the hill intact.  I only had beer, a nice selection of which is available on tap;  the wine list is a disgrace---but since even with their miserable selection they're in company with almost every bar in the City, and better still than most (have you seen the wine list at the Lush Lounge?) it'd be more surprising if they actually had decent wine.   At $6.50 a glass, the prices are right.  I'd prefer to have the option of paying more for better, or buying half bottles of decent stuff.  That is not an option.  The Wharf gets more abuse than it deserves.  The best restaurant in the area remains In n Out,  there's a great little wine bar in the Cannery (which unfortunately runs in the opposite direction---at $16. to $20. a glass, the wine is great, but who wants to spend that kind of money at a bar?)  And Normans sells Mitchells Ice Cream, around the corner, despite not having the visibility of Ben and Jerry's and that awful new chain ice-cream joint whose name I can't remember.   The Gold Dush Lounge brings a welcome respite of 20th Century pre-foodie bar ambience to the Wharf, and I will look forward to dropping in from time to time.  By the way, as one poster noted, the place is ADA compliant in the worst way, a fat person in a super-sized wheel chair could tend bar;  but, despite Parisian boulevards for aisles, the place works.  And the "F" line rolls right up to the front door.

J0Hs9R77Z2Sxjz5CBrEiGA.review_text: Not the same as the old place but a good reproduction.  Same cheap drinks.  Same decor.  Same 49er up front.  The crowd is very different though.  I sort of miss that.  Where else would you have seen people lining up to go INTO the bar at 6:00 AM.  I tried one of their $5.00 half sandwiches and they are a good deal.  They do seem to run out later in the day so be early.

btY6sVjwj8tLNR3j5J5zzA.review_text: We had some great bloody mary's and a margarita and they were awesome!  They market and sell O'doul's mixes and I have to say they were something that we will be looking for in our local Kroger store.

MxdPk4L3goC3WyjMAiET2w.review_text: It's worth noting two things. First, the lounge has moved to the Fisherman's Wharf area. Second, there's no food here--just drinks.  With that said I had a fun and enjoyable time here with their decent selection of draft beers and variety of mixed drinks. They have a very long bar, and frequently have live musicians playing at night. With a number of HDTVs, it's also a decent place to try and watch a game.  If you're looking for a place to get some good drinks in the Fisherman's Wharf area, check out the Gold Dust Lounge.

wTpoaW3kuqDAt0ojKhjaww.review_text: A clean, classy, low-key bar with good drinks and great company!  My cocktail waitress, Melissa, was sweet, funny, and has an infectious smile and laugh. It's impossible to leave in a bad mood when she's there!

lnVHFR5kjlszg6QlKIeCjQ.review_text: I was so thirsty for a margarita, after walking for several miles. (Powell Station to Aquatic Park on 07/04/2013) I used to frequent to old location on Powell St. I was glad that see that famous marquee! and of course offering the $3.50 margarita or champagne. The place is bigger and does not feel like a tourist trap. Liz works there!

1yeS87Cj8DhbLXSLYxzIzw.review_text: I've reviewed the old Gold Dust when it lived for many decades on Union Square. (5 stars from me) They had to move because the landlord sold the building. I'll miss it in that former location. They seem to have faithfully preserved the look of the old place here on Fisherman's Wharf. There were throngs there the day my husband and I went to its grand opening recently. But we've been back since- at the cocktail hour on a weekday and no one was there! I hope they are able to succeed in this new spot. The Gold Dust has been a San Francisco institution.

cgAhU-Vi4yV2ncQOf5ECZA.review_text: Stopped by during a weekday early evening. Great selection of beer, had a decent variety of Single-Malt Scotch which is what I was after. We ordered a Harps pint and a glass of Balvenie and sat at a table. Great atmosphere and we were ready to order some more drinks and settle in for a few hours when the live music started. This clown turned up the volume so loud I thought my ears were going to bleed. We, and the table next to us, asked the waitress to turn down the volume but she said she was not "allowed" . We left after one drink and told the bouncer they needed to lower the noise.

Wkqj0jAZZmtRLcLuPj_eqw.review_text: Oh the Gold Dust.  What can I say - Lots of great memories, in the old location as well as the new, super cool atmosphere, kind of takes you back in time...anything and everything to drink, only hot dogs and kettle corn on the menu...wish there were more offerings in the way of soaking up the alcohol pub food, but you can't beat this place for a great drink and good live music.  Every time.  Thanks for sticking it out all these years!

s79vzEzqavL_29pmraXZBA.review_text: I liked it for the entertainment value.   Pretty sure I watched a coke deal go down between two mid-20ish girls and one of the bartenders right in front of my gf and I though.  The girls were at the bar, and one of the bartenders wearing sunglasses and strolling around like he was the king of the place (maybe he owns it, I don't know) walks up, and money and something else changed hands.  Then the girls both run off into the back of the building and are gone for 45 minutes.  One of them comes back out without the other one and is super jittery and emotional and just looked, well, looked coked up LOL.  My gf  then goes into the ladies room and the other one is in there barfing up a lung.  Girlfriend didn't appreciate the whole "low key" drug deal thing that again happened right in front of us, nor did she appreciate the vomiting in the bathroom.  But, hey, it's a bar, and I guess that stuff happens.  So, go for the cheap beers, the fact that the place appears to pretty much be open all night, or go to watch skanks get coked up.  Whatever!   Score!

splfcS_Z6XSMmS0j0c2Y6w.review_text: I liked the old place better when it was in Union Square just because it feels sort of out of place next to Ripley's Believe It Or Not and t-shirt shops at Fisherman's Wharf. I feel like when it was downtown, it fit in more ... here it's just kind of there. I know that was out of the owner's control ... but still, just a vibe.  The inside of this place is great ... cavernous ... over the top ... it is designed to resemble a saloon from the 1860s, complete with faux globed gas lights and velvet pattered wallpaper. It looks like a cross between Liberace's bedroom and a brothel from the wild west. You could search high and low and you'll probably never see another place like it.  The bar is more modern with big glass refridgerators of beer and a huge flat screen tv with 6 different screens (most of them sports). The front has a piano and the sides are velvet booths.  One thing I HATE about this place is the music. They used to have a great band that did covers of songs from the 1960s - 1980s. The last 3 times I went in they had a pretty bad singer who was on the piano. The piano music was way too loud ... so loud you couldn't have a conversation ... and the weird thing is that they left the cool 1950s music playing on the speakers while he was singing which meant two songs going on at the same time.  Also, when you are drinking in a bar at midnight at Fisherman's Wharf ... you don't want to hear depressing piano versions of slow John Legend songs. The guy was playing very melancholy songs on the piano which were borderline depressing me. It would be one thing if he was banging out some Jerry Lee Lewis music ... but to play depressing, slow songs ... not what I am looking for when I am drinking in a bar with velvet wallpaper and gold mirrored walls.  The bartenders are super nice here ... and will pretty much go out of their way to get you whatever you want. They all seem happy and like they enjoy working there. I got the vibe that everyone is a close knit group, and that's always a good thing for patrons to see. The bouncer was a big 'thuggy' and kind of gruff but on The Wharf, I'm sure he's seen his fair share of shit so he might be battle hardened.  There are less tourists who drink here and more locals. Lack of drink specials and a dark kind of vibe don't always lend itself to the tourist crowd. The bar is immaculately clean ... which must be hard to do because believe it or not, this bar is carpeted!  If not for the piano music, this would be a great place I'd recommend to anyone. One of my favorite dive bars in San Francisco.

ILz8ApVEgTqbv5LnC6PyuA.review_text: Awesome! It's the same spot, just nicer and it doesn't smell! There is the fact that it's smack dab in tourist trap hell. But if you can get past that, there isn't a better bar (with great live music) in the area...

beYxtgReTb09Dsg-4mH4SA.review_text: We stopped in, while the kids were finishing up the mirror maze next door.  The place is clean, and decor screams, Classy Brothel, in a good way. Grabbed a glass of wine and a soda, price was reasonable, and a glass of water-available to all.  Bathroom was also clean, especially for a bar, especially in a tourist area.   Didn't really have a big opinion on the place, until later, except to say that it was a nice experience, for a place we spent maybe 20 minutes at,  Except, I forgot to grab my credit card.  :(  Didn't realize where it might be til late, and left a message on their machine.   I gotta say, there's few feelings worse than realizing you left your credit card (debit) linked to your checking account, in a bar, mid-way through a weekend away.  They called, told me they had it, and to call back in the AM.  I did that, a very kind gentleman answered, and let me know they had it, and I could swing by any time.  We did, I ran in with cash in hand to tip whomever was awesome enough to keep it safe, and ran into the same nice gentleman. I thanked him profusely, he said, "I just hope you had a good time while you were here, come again".  Customer service? Above and beyond.

iZryWD-4yfQjEdNv9OJ_4g.review_text: The ghost of the old, venerable, beloved, iconic Gold Dust as it existed at Union Square is officially dead. There's no point now crying over its demise, the wounds, still sore, are not bleeding fresh anymore. The bar,  its unbelievable happy hours, raucous visitor/local crowd, authentic period decor are gone.  Enter the Fisherman's Wharf reincarnation of Gold Dust. Granted, they tried. The owners did their best to imitate the atmosphere and for a while, even the menu, of the old place. And for a while, it worked. Or maybe, it was the nostalgia speaking. Granted, the location put it firmly into SF's touristland, as no Sanfranciscan frequences the area unless he or she works in the tacky souvenir and cheap jacket business.   And so the place starts appearing, well, sad. It's huge - far too big for a bar. It's decor looks cheap. The paintings on the walls look fake. But most and foremost, the happy hour as we know it, is gone. I'm not even talking about $4.75 irish coffees and champagnes *during* the happy hour - a far cry from 2.95 and 3.50 that they used to cost at the old place. No, I'm talking about the happy hour ending at 6:30 instead of 8:30 as it has for decades. Now that, is not Gold Dust. That is anti-Gold Dust. And thus, I shall visit this place no more. I'd rather drink my Irish coffee, as overpriced as it is there, at Buena Vista Cafe. That's right.

qQUrTFRKkka68b1V9-00gQ.review_text: The decoration is pretty awesome !!! It's a good place to chill with friends ^__^

n21lmDkbnDHNT8H5iBfy8w.review_text: This review is specifically for the Irish Coffee.  AMAZING!    I'm a tour guide at the Wharf and I have tried pretty much every Irish from there to North Beach.  I've had some good ones, but usually have to pay between $7 and $9. This made-to-order gem is only $3.75!  You can have two for the price of one and still have money to tip.   Some other places, specifically one who claims to have invented the Irish Coffee, charge $9 and they are made 20 at a time.    Well Done!

0ZiBVQ142c6RU7QALxV5YQ.review_text: The Gold Dust Lounge is full of wonderful and joyous people. If you are looking for live music with a mix of karaoke with visitors from all over the world this is a place to visit. Used my vocals too.

QsMLT06-s4vltVIz8DgpMw.review_text: Drinks are relatively cheap, especially considering that Fisherman's Wharf is a touristy area. I came here with a huge group (about 20), and there was still enough room to spread out on a Saturday night. Bartenders were nice, they had live music which I always appreciate. The crowd is a mix of late 20's/early 30s, and baby boomers.   The decor reminds me of an old Vegas casino, and has plenty of TVs if you want to watch a game. My only real knock against this place was that a staff member was  rude to me. She also happened to knock over a stool onto me which gave me a gash on my leg, which was not appreciated lol. Aside from that, I lived through it and had a nice time.

E45odMHs7ot5VEmmGRXFWA.review_text: On a recent trip dow to San francisco, this sticks out as our favourite place we hung out at. It was a nice break from the crowds. We ended up putting in a bit of a shift here as we enjoyed it so much, mostly because of the amazing bartender Ken!! Thanks Ken, from your pals from Vancouver BC! You're awesome! :)

o8FrwBegKjm959oVKSeNeA.review_text: Beautiful new location!  They really put a lot into this new location and it's amazing; you'll feel like Sean Connery walking into this place!  They really need a $3.50 vodka martini to go with their other great drink specials.

POE-8YwzR1OTEQBcENP1IA.review_text: dive bar heaven! i don't know the history, i read about it but i look forward to making a stop here everytime i am in SF! and yes, the electrical outlets under the bar are a major plus!

mhPZwD3G594BNoSY1SMoRg.review_text: It was quite literally filled with senior citizens

lBaoq2G8xXrSX_esMQXM-A.review_text: I've only been to the new location once but it was a pleasant surprise running into on the Wharf.  It is not the typical touristy chain spot.  I'm so glad it didn't disappear.  They kept the old antique charm of the place in Union Square but now it's new with old world charm.  Best of all they don't rob you blind for a drink like a lot of the places in touristy areas do, vodka and soda $6.75.  Although we don't go to Fisherman's Wharf often this will be a regular stop when in the area.  It is simply a unique spot in a hectic touristy area.

jYocGA7-XqK0K5uidEFc8A.review_text: I just flew into town sat evening 1-17 to celebrate my birthday. We dropped off luggage and went looking for a place to sit down and have a drink. There was live music! We stopped in here. Met some locals and chatted with musician. Ordering a beer was an ordeal. It was not crowded yet the bartender seemed very annoyed by us- we interrupted his conversations every time. Ask to watch a basketball game...he changed channel and literally threw the remote complaining it was the 3rd time he changed it.  We were having a great time with the locals but had to leave because of the poor service. It is a great little spot and I am hoping this guy was just having a really bad day.

_BAmfTUcpzkXARvnLRj3GQ.review_text: Was recommended to this place by neighboring shop. Happy hour all day until 6:30 - $3.75 key lime margaritas. Does it get any better? Oh, it does. The ambiance was nice, very elegant and "classy". Not too many patrons, but not surprising because we were there around 3:30PM. Our bartender was very relaxed, creating a comfortable atmosphere. Would definitely go back again.

XRmnHVEWW79N_odOei8PGg.review_text: The Good: Prompt service with great staff. Clean, classy well kept bar. Reasonably priced.  The Bad: The bar's policy for my Amazon Local voucher. So I bought a $20 for $10 voucher months ago and the voucher clearly states either bring a print out or show the voucher on your phone to redeem.   With it being 2014 and all I showed the Asian bartender, with thick glasses and a protruding chin, my voucher on my phone and he proceeded to tell me I had to have a printout and they will not honor the electronic one on my phone. He said "they had meetings regarding this" like I cared about that.  I was there with friends for a good time and I just did not feel it was the time to argue so I left pretty annoyed.   Dear Gold Dust,  If this is the case your prepaid voucher policy is lousy and honestly against the law. I feel you offered them to generate business where in this case it will cause me to take the option of ever going to your estsblishment off the table for good because my drinking friends "had a meeting regarding this".   Further I will refer to you now as Fools Gold Dust should the need arise in the future.  Thanks for everything.

wjYtZFVzs2sIfwbUYb9EIA.review_text: I attended the opening night festivities and had a great time.  I love the bar's look and feel.  It feels just like the old bar, but new and fans of the old place won't be disappointed.  The place is much much bigger than the old spot and I like it.  The bartenders were nice and served us quickly.  I'm kinda glad they lost their lease at the old spot b/c it forced them to move and start fresh again.  I definitely recommend hitting up the new location for drinks and good times.  The live band is always a good time.

Q7Qj6rTSIC6UVQ0a9xSyEQ.review_text: Tried to get into the Powell St. location right before they were forced out but the crowd was overwhelming.    Yesterday was the second chance and the bar was pretty empty and it was 5:30 so the Irish Coffee was $3.75. The bartender, who came from the original location poured a strong Jameson.  The drink was so good and cheap another round was necessary.  Many of the fixtures such as the chandeliers were brought from Powell St.   Don't miss reading the history of the Gold Dust in the back hallway by the bathrooms.

Mdf1iuXDsDyqnUrv5pG9lQ.review_text: Ken was a boss. Knew how to take care of his customers. Would def come back when I'm back in town.

eyLbWDFrvLsa_q85htmZlw.review_text: This was a really nice place. Just happened to walk by and decided to stop in. The servers were really attentive. They have a really long bar or booths for whatever you like. The interior has a old school feel to it and there was live music to compliment the ambiance. Definitely a good place to stop in and have a drink.

AvfMaqcH21JUBbb23ZjRYg.review_text: looks great, was here last night, lots of strobe lights, along with a guy dressed as a cowboy out front inviting people in for a drink, cheers guys!

AcyysNzAxCMIKOv5swqL2w.review_text: Bartender Ken is the BEST! I go to Gold Dust Lounge every so often when I make my occasional In-N-Out trips, and by far Ken makes the best margaritas there. I met him during the day a few months ago while I was waiting for a friend to finish up a tour of Alcatraz, and he kept me company. He's very personable, friendly, and has a positive outlook on life. A genuine human!   I'm sad they moved this to the Wharf, and that happy hour ends earlier as I no longer can make it by the time it ends causing me to go here less often, but it's still a relaxing place to go to with friends and sip cheap margaritas.

CmMYi_gqAfBRU0scy53PGQ.review_text: Great place to go in Fisherman's Wharf. Friendly staff, good prices and some live music! I'll definitely be back!

O7R6HblHCzsFeFOjVK6Y1Q.review_text: I love this place!! Coincidently came across this place while walkin around the area and saw their sign "$2 jello shots" my gf and I were like HELLL YESS so we came in and got one each and went straight to SF dungeon next door lol  SF dungeon was boring enough so we went back here to get more drinks and Ash was the best bartender ever. He's funny, talkative, super nice and very friendly!! Talkin to him feels like talkin to a friend, we ended up stayin there all day long and he was very attentive! I'm so happy I came in here, met him and will definitely be coming back!  Thanks Ash! :)

XJgRdHOsgypEba4oKwAh1w.review_text: It's very hard for me to rate this spot. The old Gold Dust in Union Square was a truly wonderful place--a dive bar with history and character. But greedy developers decided another woman's clothing store was more important than a true part of San Francisco history, so the Gold Dust moved to a new location on the Wharf.  It gets an A for effort, and it is easily among the best bars in the Wharf in terms of service, people watching and character.  Still, it is a shadow of its former self--too clean and too nice to live up to its name and reputation. Maybe in 20 or 30 years it will have soaked up the spilled beer, dreams and stories that made the old Gold Dust great, but until then it is only a good bar instead of a great one.

3C2gP95BENm01k_-kmSi4Q.review_text: so happy to see this place opened back up! cant wait to pop in next time i'm in sf!!!

x_bpi_SRk-UNQ6-gfNJqnA.review_text: Come here on a Monday night if you're a tourist staying at the Wharf and have nowhere better to go.  Ajay was in town for his aunt's 50th birthday, so after dinner we ended up at this little lively spot right on the Wharf.  Pros: +Live music +Cheap "Industry Hour"/Happy Hour drinks-$4/glass of wine  Cons: -Live Band sucked; horrible Sinatra covers -the wine tasted like water -the water tasted like acid and you have to pour it yourself after the first glass even though the bartender is doing nothing  -Hungry Hungry Pongy

elIIKDSR2aSt6R0LTr5CcA.review_text: Love this place! Stiff, cheap drinks and meet many of the locals who were excited to share all of the fun places to check out while in the city. I wish Gold Dust was closer to San Diego. When in town I will definitely be back.

azb_ZEoas3teX1oyQbwlBg.review_text: been here twice and I love this place. Drinks are great and staff are really friendly.

_2h9MazCl88U4Bnry1jHFQ.review_text: Ok Ok   the common comment I hear is the same as I feel--you just can't duplicate the original Gold Dust with it's funky atmosphere and smell (yes-I said smell) Although they did a pretty good job with the new location it isn't as intimate as the old place. I think it will grow on folks over the years---Give it a try!

nYDozThOT6SxLzLQC8U14A.review_text: Love the new Gold Dust. I like the 1890s decor and live music.  Bartender Rudy is the best!  Like to come on weekend mornings when he is working.  Very friendly and makes a great drink.

Gh7a3aAOlB2zMRocFzGEZg.review_text: When my friends and I saw the $3.75 Irish Whiskey sign, we walked in to what resembled an old Reno casino lounge. It was then we knew we were in for a good time.  Had I known about Gold Dust Lounge, I wouldn't have chucked away $9 for the same Irish coffee at Buena Vista Café up the street. Doh!!  Two hours later, our bartender knew entirely too much about our personal lives and us of his. The crowd here is pretty eclectic - from sailors to Australian tourists to locals like us. I felt right at home.  This place is legit!

hAId-4tnZPCz0pxambt3pA.review_text: Great atmosphere in Fisherman's Wharf right on Jefferson street.  Looking for a a good vibe, large drink selection, live music and a friendly crowd? The place is clean and classy looking on the inside. Great place to hang with with a friend or a group. This is a good place to go.   Staff are engaging and attentive. Band was great (Johnny Z and the Camaros) Customers were friendly and a lot of fun as well. Lot's of dancing here.  If I am in the neighborhood again I will be back.

ue3iTFnrXssV7tC5rPog3w.review_text: We were here in June and came back to get a drink while walking on the wharf.  The bartenders are very friendly and attentive.  The bathrooms are gorgeous and sparkling clean.  The drinks are great.

oQWIurx_ZLKvMUjkzBH7FA.review_text: I can't say enough about how kind the people are at the Gold Dust. The piano player and the manager were really kind to us while we were at the club. We ended up running off and leaving our camera in the lounge.  We were amazed when they called us and told us they found our camera and would mail it to our residence in Atlanta.  I can't say enough! We had several people call and give us their phone numbers to let them know if our camera did not show up.  Thank you so much! Great, honest people.....

lHqA_D7nAK9xw_Xg08dM_w.review_text: Stopped in here after a day of walking around San Fran and making the rounds at the wharf.  We had so much fun!  Happy hour was awesome and we started off with some prosecco which is very rare for us but it was the special and why not?  The bartender was super friendly and atmosphere was very retro cool.  There was a lounge singer that made things even more interesting.  Not everyone appreciated his skills but we sure did and had a great time singing along.  We even happened to sit between some locals so it was neat that even they stop in here.  So take a break from the wharf and have a cheap drink and enjoy the music!

jAiGoRmj3eAkeH_3KfudXg.review_text: Me: Does it smell in here? Him: Like what? Me: Bad farts and Axe Body Spray Him: ...yeah  To be fair, the whole place didn't smell bad, but one of the tables around us was doing a real good job of polluting the air. That, coupled with a server that ignored us to the point of almost leaving, didn't create a great first impression to say the least.  After an afternoon at the Exploratorium, we decided on an impromptu bar crawl to kill time before our dinner. Based on the reviews, we thought we'd give it a shot; on paper it had the makings of a place we'd like despite being in one of the most touristy parts of town. We were wrong.  I never visited the original Gold Dust Lounge, I think I would have liked it. The new one took obvious pains to recreate the idea of the old Gold Dust and an old saloon feel. They succeeded with the idea of an old place, but failed in terms of feel. I can't put my finger on it, but compared to pictures of the original, it lacks warmth and feels gimmicky. The space is long and narrow; we weren't sure why, but it really felt like there should be a casino attached to it. Behind a bar in the back was a band playing covers.  We came, we saw, we drank. Will we come back? Probably not, nothing left us wanting more.

R12RE7bT8LNnGC4U3rE9tA.review_text: Came here because of the high reviews, left disappointed. Mojito has no real mint, a sad state for the price. The sample platter didn't come with pieces listed in menu. I get that it's an agreement with a restaurant next door but you'd think they would hold them to a standard if they're going to offer it. The bartender is the only saving grace.

7eAGQZCnI_UUkiaUsZjuog.review_text: This place is THE BEST and probably only awesome attraction the fisherman's wharf has to offer. The door guy Chris was hilarious and super polite. The music was Spectacular! He was even on Americas got talent! The bartenders were half and half. There was an Asian kid with crazy hair who was more than likely the best bartender to serve me and then there was another young bartender with a goofy soul patch who more than likely won't be working there longer. He was flustered and grouchy all night so we stayed with the funny Asian guy. Great place, great decor, great people.

dusl6MaLSfYbE83_iVO2KQ.review_text: If you don't already know, look up the history of SF's famous Gold Dust Lounge and you might (like me) find it a little sad that they were forced to move. It has only been in its new locale for a little over a year - and it's still pretty neat as they tried to move as much of the old stuff to the new spot as possible - but it's unfortunately now in the EXTRA touristy Wharf area.   During the day the GDL is still a nice place to step in, escape the hordes of tourists (most don't seem to realize it's open during the day), grab a nice cold one or classic cocktail on the cheap, charge your cell phone employing the plugs at the bar...enjoy the frescos of beautiful cherubs and voluptuous naked ladies and take retreat in their nice and cool and clean bathrooms.

SclmXBFXOwbSwuUbzpEjtw.review_text: Thoroughly enjoyed this spot. We came in on a Sunday afternoon. Atmosphere was nice. The tables were cleaned and received great services & drinks.   I'll be back!

YUmdD3R1HoobmscAjw982w.review_text: Went here last Saturday night to celebrate my brothers 30th. Called ahead to see if they would be able to accommodate a party of 25 around 11ish. The GM was wonderful on the phone and even told me to ask for him or the bar manager and said they would have the band sing to my brother for his bday. When we showed up, the bar manager ran over and told the band it was my brothers bday, and what do you know they made a total big deal about it and it was AWESOME! I am so excited that this place hasn't lost its personal touch. Drinks are great, prices are great and the staff even better. I can't want to come back to SF and visit the Gold Dust again!

C3rZpoQCzH58DoQojuUfGA.review_text: This place was really chill, it was a little crammed, but the bartenders were awesome and the crowd was too!

nPQApLF0Uksil8JN9YokEA.review_text: Bartender was attentive and pleasant. We came on a Monday evening and ordered a Fireball and a Stella. The bar is very beautiful. I love the angel painting on the ceiling!

7dDluT5TxIHbuZTGAglBFQ.review_text: I only went to the old location 2 times, but this is definitely a tittle nicer.  Granted now its kinda in a touristy spot, when i went here there was some friendly people and a piano player that was actually darn good.  Took a bit longer at first to get drinks, and the prices are a little high, but hey its the city on the wharf, i'm sure their rent is threw the roof, a nice pub to stop in for a bit with friends on the way to the best night of your life.

X0WkMJIcgQ2en-WQuF0IZw.review_text: Love the new location! The atmosphere is great!! Great staff and great look! Perfect for after work drinks or after walking on the pier!!

30K9UEgEcwWYyRL_dAAQxw.review_text: Ok now that's a good margarita and the price was good. Adrianna was so friendly and quick unlike the arrogant bartender who she relived for lunch or whatever. He egged the tourists next to us to give him a good yelp review by name. What a jerk!

JcC4oyByYbZCJq5Ybvg6SQ.review_text: The decor is funky and has an old vibe to it. There's always some form of music whether it be a live band, singers, or a DJ. The drinks are very cheap especially for being on the wharf so there are a lot of tourists.  I'm definitely one to come back whenever I can though. The manager is great as well as a couple of speedy bartenders. I did experience rather rude service from one of the female bartenders. She was short and Latina I'm assuming, she gave me quite an attitude, almost as if she didn't want to serve me.

4IzHh2Cfoddv3ZXZqqtZzA.review_text: Opening day folks. It's been too long. Make sure you get an Irish Coffee. And tip $5 for a ring a ding ding of the cable car bell!  The grand re-opening of this iconic San Francisco watering hole was long overdue.  Their new location on Fisherman's Wharf is a far cry from the old digs near Union Square, but no worries, it's easily accessible via street car from BART, or a Cable Car ride and a few block walk.    The new place is a modern re-telling of the old joint.  It has the soul of the Gold Dust in a more modern setting.  The bar is HUGE and there are many more tables than the old location.  The bathrooms are bigger, way less claustrophobic, and they have Dyson Air Blades if that sort of thing is important to you.  They have a bigger beer selection as well.    This place is different than the old location, but it has that same feel to it.  The styling is similar, and the tourist/local vibe is definitely there.  I'm sad that the old place is gone, but this is a rejuvenated Gold Dust Lounge for the next 40 years.  The prices are bit higher, $6.50 for a glass of Champagne, but it is the only really decent non-restaurant bar in the area, and it's still cheaper than just about anywhere else in SF.    Johnny Z and the Camaro's are back too.  This band knows every song ever written, but they are known to change the words now and then to fit the local area, for instance, Johnny Cash never sang, "I shot a man in Oakland, just to watch him die" but Johnny Z and the Camaro's do, to much appreciation.  Feel free to drop $5 in their tip jar to request your favorite sing a long song, and they'll oblige you.    It's sad that many of the long time faces of the Gold Dust, like Lorraine and Chuck aren't here, but times change, and we get to have the Gold Dust for another few generations.  There are new relationships to build, and more drinks to drink.    Long live the Gold Dust lounge, and thanks to everyone that worked so hard to save this legendary San Francisco drink joint.    As Herb Caen once said, "anyone for a nightcap?"

Bd8BEsZHRn0on03N9Kt3jg.review_text: This place is shady. I got overcharged for 3 drinks on my credit card. I wasn't drunk at all so I noticed immediately when i closed my tab. I informed the bartender, he apologized and told me he reversed the charges on my card and gave me a receipt. The next day I looked on my bank statement and he didn't. I called the bar and spoke with the alleged manager, a guy with a British accent, and he also apologized and told me he would reverse the charges to my card. It never happened!

4KibpNERNJ3G2loczETtBg.review_text: Was one of the only bars in San Francisco that provided us five star service. Both bartenders were excellent, conversational, and made drinks that were on point. Bloody Mary and Goslings Dark & Stormy were perfect.   I was super intrigued by the bar's history and the unfortunate fight it sustained to maintain its original location and attempt to attain a historical landmark. It's a shame that an Express took its original place in Union square rather than an establishment from 1918 that survived prohibition and welcomed such stars as Janis Joplin. Best Wishes to the owners at their new location!

TA5f9rpPGllhrjhIor8jNA.review_text: Ooh, my new favorite sorta-dive! This place is super easy to find, big, comfy, with pretty good service. Happy hour included a 3.50 champagne (woohoo!). My coworker and I stopped in to kill time before the ferry, and it was just perfect. I would absolutely go back. It feels like a well-maintained old casino lounge, if that makes any sense. It was comfortable. And not at all worn down, like you might think from the name. I could sit here and drink and talk all night.   It did get pretty loud at the end...lots of groups yelling over one another.

OMoBzr4FhDkk7yV8zYtmiw.review_text: An afternoon chatting with a sailor is an afternoon well spent.    This location has accumulated a few new regulars from down by the docks.  It's just not the same old Gold Dust though.  There's too much light to provide the dim, coziness found when at Powell.  It's missing the intimacy that I had grown to love.  On the other hand, it's cool in an entirely new way.  There's even enough space to stop by with a group of more than four.  If there wasn't anything to compare to and I just stumbled across this bar I would have still had a great time.  Potent drinks have that effect on me.

I4AExHCd-bQ5y9W6gxZSCQ.review_text: I knew of this place for years as they were on Powell Street, but never have the interest of coming in. Now they're at The Wharf and wanted to check it out.  As my friend and I entered, we were greeted by a greeter wearing period clothing. The décor was good and brought me back in time of a different era. Though it wasn't too busy by the time we came in on Saturday late afternoon early evening period.  The staff were friendly and help us within a minute or so after we sat down at a table. Our waitress was friendly and made us feel like we're at Cheers. Though we only had 1 drink each, the price was very competitive.  When I'm in the general area of The Wharf, I'll keep this place in mind and come back.

Fet_lXAW7dLvySLx2zIJ8g.review_text: I went during the day for the drink specials.  Good deals and the place was super clean.  If you know the area most places are run down and dirty.  The Gold Dust Lounge was clean, bartender was super nice but best of all the BATHROOMS were super clean and I needed to use it, if you know what I mean... I will be making this a regular pit stop for drinks and facilities every time I'm in the area. . Good job Gold Dust Lounge staff. ..

lJVWX2Va1CAcc-S3_bHW-g.review_text: We were here on a Tuesday night, not crowded at all...and it took the bartender 20 minutes to even get his attention. Not the best service around. Don't think I would come here again. The guy playing the piano and covers of oldies doesn't really go with the Victorian atmosphere either. Sorry. Two stars.

DJ0AyCrN7efeR4x56N3oKQ.review_text: Dancing frogs. Synth Michael Jackson on the jazz piano. 3.50 margaritas. Go.

fYnAmjaSWGnCEjy-_dVTVg.review_text: Horrible bar with nothing more to offer than horrible service with terrible cocktails and music. If you wish to find a boring old cougar bar then search no further.  This place is a huge disappointment to San Francisco!!!

9p8G8MvSuj24QW5ljiHv2g.review_text: This place....beyond amazing.   Came here the other day to meet up with my friends who were bar hopping the city on a ghetto Mexican school bus. We walked into what felt like an old Las Vegas casino bar minus the slot machines and plus a piano man and an awesome front door lady and waitress.   3.75 strong Irish coffees and mimosas, a fun atmosphere and just an overall awesome place. The lady at the front (I believe her name was Jo) got a Michael Jackson impersonator to come and dance for our whole party of 40 people and the piano man was taking requests all evening.   I'm sure this place has a lot of history and definitely a great place to go and grab a drink if you are looking for something fun and new or even if you are just visiting from out of town.

g3SoH-xgNzn9W_r1L02sYg.review_text: Talk about a bad imitation of Reno.

gxhL4EPRyUEmx7jZhQTQvg.review_text: I'm at the Wharf regularly and have been my "go to" bar. Can't go wrong with $3.50 drinks (Irish Coffees/Margaritas/Champagne/Bud) anywho I like Victoria the early daytime bartender she's funny and as a native SF she knows her North Beach/Wharf history. Very cool. The place is really neat check out the ceiling (cherubs galore). It is a facsmilie of the "old" Gold Dust on Powell St (Union Square) but a much larger venue. Still has the crazy band...and Mark the manager is great. They now have a gal at the door who is super friendly inviting folks in.

3yONylE7yEy7Ly37NJgauQ.review_text: the servers were not to tentative but my friends and i had a great time there talking and catching up. There margaritas are pretty good and usual fare for drinks. The night we went, they had live music which was pretty cool but if your sitting close to the entrance it can get pretty loud and hard to hold a conversation. A plus is that there are a couple of places around there that you can get drinks so you can always go bar hopping.

HMH2cyQ9rxloMImAH5bO4Q.review_text: Perfect spot for a beer or cocktail while cruzing in FW. Cool bartenders and flatscreens to watch sports. They have snacks and water table if u need a nibble.. Perfect lik spot in the wharf

F7PWK3UJdJZLm2HLtMxzsg.review_text: I made it to the old location and saw the new location while we were walking to meet friends for dinner.  We thought we'd go in and have a drink for old time sake.  We waited for a good 20 minutes before I flagged a waitress down for our drink order.  Hubby wouldn't let me walk up to the bar on principle.  Once we placed our order we waited and waited.  15 minutes later I asked another waitress about our order; she said it was coming.  Another 5 minutes and we decided to leave, saw the original waitress.  She said she gave our order to someone and complained about the waitresses working.  With this type of service I hope they can pay Fishermans Wharf rent.  I'm local to  the city, but won't be back there.

MAatw6IQHYCqeATbHHMz1w.review_text: Sunday afternoon, trying to pass time before eventually heading to the Airport to go back to San Diego.  My friends and I were wandering around Fisherman's Wharf /Pier 39 checking out Forbes Island (a restaurant/island). The place didn't open until 5 pm and it's only about 1:30.  As we perused Yelp listings for a bar, my friend Yvonne suggested the Gold Dust Lounge (we always want to seek out possible dive bars).  Since the area is full of tourists of every kind (families, foreigners, outliers (people who live away from San Francisco but close enough to drive).  First good sign, no one under 21.  Of course this is early Sunday afternoon and you will not expect a drunken crowd but we also didn't expect a really clean and obviously remodeled Gold Dust lounge.  In it's heyday, it might have looked like this, and probably got rundown before getting fixed up again.  It was not at all crowded with about a half dozen or more people sitting around drinking (some even had pizza - probably ordered outside since the food menu for this bar is minimal).  Another nod that we are now in the modern Gold Dust lounge, availability of plugs, not necessarily for your computer but sometimes your phone suddenly gets battery drain after seeking out spots in the area or getting your Uber ride.  The bartender was fairly nice and not talkative, several tvs (4) showed various sports events (range from tennis to wakeboarding to baseball - i think the owner is an Oakland A's fan not SF Giants but I couldn't see any indication except conversation).  So if you ever find yourself dragged by your family in Pier 39 and Fisherman's wharf where everybody is eating their bread bowl clam chowder in any corner or sidewalk space available, check this place out.  It might save your sanity from the huge throngs of tourists around.   P.S,.  The Spicy Bloody Mary was priced right.  And yes it was spicy but a glass of water is easily available by the bar.

HwSiM9-0r57Fzo2YuSMeFw.review_text: Shot of Jameson and a Rolling Rock beer for $6. Sounds good to me! Decor is nice. Not too busy and quick service.

z1In_1TfnQ6kFu4Sxl7nnw.review_text: This place was pretty cool! I really liked their Jameson and coffee drink and the live music was awesome. The workers were all very nice and the drinks were reasonably priced. If I'm ever in the area again, I'd for sure come back.

ZH2BsTXtOrzgNLFGDFsogA.review_text: So we are in the middle of ultra touristy Fisherman's Wharf looking for somewhere to sit down, get something to drink, and take it easy.  I am not a bar person in general, but if they all were like this, I may become one.  Amazing happy hour.  Low cost margaritas that are not watered down.  Decent wine selection.  Especially friendly service.  Quiet and intimate enough to share quiet time with someone and lively enough to be fun.  Don't let the outside appear steer you away.  Great place to stop.

T4E1PMvIF78PKVMXnYcuRw.review_text: This place is great.  I used to go to the original location and I was skeptical about their move to Fisherman's Wharf.  However, I think it makes the place a lot of fun.  It's a nice mix of locals and out-of-towners.  They have excellent drink specials.  It has the old look and feel, but it's much larger, meaning you'll always get a seat which is nice.

JvWLFYC1GB7W6al-a-X_Hg.review_text: I left my cell phone here and they contacted me to return it. Pizza was also really tasty!

MZuvl0oUK3QSv7faGx9i5w.review_text: This place was recommended to us by a chatty drunk at Fog Harbor earlier in the day. When you get a recommendation like that, how can you stay away?  Supposedly, this is the less touristy location, but it may just be the only drinking establishment open past 11pm. Their drinks are the cheapest you'll find in the area, especially if you're a beer drinker.  The location boasted a deep and very long bar that can comfortably seat what I'd estimate to be 30 people, maybe more. There was only one bartender on staff when we visited, so drink service was slow, but he seemed to be relatively efficient given the short staff at the business.  They have a cocktail menu and I tried the 7th inning stretch, which was a tasteful combination of sweet and bitter. My "better half" had a Cosmo, made just like a Cosmo should be made.  If there isn't live music, they have classic songs playing from the 60s and 70s for the most part that add to the interesting theme and ambiance of the business. There was a live pianist when we visited that was very talented, and was very fun for a sing-a-long.  The sloppy drunk woman with uncontrollable limbs that were constantly pounding at my back took away from our experience. Her ability to continually obtain negative attention ultimately ended our time of stay for the evening. Both my fiancée and I said we would have stayed longer, but were at our maximum threshold for watching a drunk, annoying, self-centered, half-dressed woman placing her every effort toward obtaining attention (but maybe that's your "thing," who am I to judge?).  I'm hoping she was eventually "cut off," which is the only action a bar can take if they notice this behavior.  The clientele aside, this is a nice, fun stop. They were the only place with any late hours around, so it's "the place" for a nightcap on your stroll back to your hotel. Drinks are cheaper than elsewhere, so you may not need that second mortgage for your second cocktail.

l0lU0PqfrwncDf1TP1XTDw.review_text: They open whenever they want so don't go by the posted hours. Other than that it's okay. Good thing there are real bars in north beach that offer better drinks in a less touristy area that open on schedule.

0AlnetQ_-a4f7kY0Sker2w.review_text: Grody.  That is the word I would have used to talk about the old Gold Dust Lounge in Union Square.  Gold-dusty-tastic is the word I would use to describe the one at Fisherman's Warf.  I'm obviously very familiar with the dictionary.    Anyway, the new Gold Dust has the same Old West/Bordello feeling that the last one tried to have.  But it is newer, cleaner, decked out with nice TVs, and has a good alcohol selection.  The staff here is super sweet, helpful, and good a multitasking.  You might even catch live music from a very entertaining Irish man.      Mixed drink menu is a bit pricey ($11-13) for about 2-3 star cocktails, but that's what you get for being in tourist central.  I'd stick with classic bar drinks (such as insert alcohol + insert 1 mixer) which are pretty good prices.  I also liked that they had some super affordable options such as $2 jello shots and $4.75 glasses of champagne before 6:30pm.  If you are dying for some food to absorb alcohol, the pizza isn't awful, but I'd stick with the drinks. I'm not quite sure what possessed us to buy a $20 16" pepperoni pizza here, but we did.  Like I said, not horrible.  Like thinner version of Costco pizza? Yeah, that sounds about right.  Overall, I was impressed with Gold Dust Lounge for what it is--a pseudo-dive bar in the heart of tourist territory.

JvydXput02Blq1KHBlkt9w.review_text: $3.75 margarita still tastes as good as if The Gold Dust was still on Powell, strong and tasty. TASTEY!

SbQ9BPmzZadcy1rKPjgrUQ.review_text: The Gold Dust was one of the first bars I came to in San Francisco when it was still by Union Square. Since its move to the Wharf, it has become a cheap tourist attraction where exhausted parents seek relief from magnet hunting with their children. The special happy hour that runs most of the day consists of watered down, pre-mixed $3.50 margaritas and poor but passable attempt at Irish coffee. The cocktail list has all the basics, but is a bit expensive. Can't complain about beer selection. Wine is alright if you aren't particular. If you hear/see the live band performing, run. While performing, the singer likes to walk around, get friendly, and even hand over the microphone (which I've witnessed twice and both times the person he chose didn't even know the song).   The ONLY reason I'm giving the new location two  stars is aesthetics. The near perfect replication of the old place down to the outside window, and the waitresses make the place easy on the eyes, especially compared to the nightmareish display Ripley's puts on next door.   The Parlor is a couple blocks down the street. Just saying.

Gw4aC-YLPG8lRdVlBmXPVQ.review_text: From the cherub painted ceilings to the crushed velvet seating this place is amazing  It's like stepping back in time   Cheap drinks & that's their focus  you aren't going to find much of a menu here  they are catering to tourists who want to grab a quick drink along the wharf   They do have tv's for watching the game Don't forget to read about the history of the place on the back of the menu  - I love knowing a places history

ihKIv3lo8IFz7O-djya-fQ.review_text: Ok, guilty pleasure perhaps, but I really, really love this place! It's in the middle of "tourist central", so that probably turns a lot of the locals off straight away. If it's any consolation, the original bar was downtown, but they were forced out by a major retailer. The drinks aren't great, it's basically what you'd expect from a dive bar (not that this place is a dive bar, just similar style of drinks -- maybe just "simple" is the best way to explain it?). For instance, if you get a Bloody Mary (which is on special for Happy Hour), you get vodka... And BM mix... perhaps a cocktail onion or two if you're lucky. Anyhow, the music is fun (80s/90s classic rock), and they even have live entertainment from time to time. Not amazing talent, but fun. Notice the theme yet?  So, naturally, whenever I have guests in the city, I bring them here. First, it's nice and close to Fisherman's Wharf (like it or not, you'll end up there if you have guests in the city), and it's--yep, you guessed it--fun!  So, last time I was there, with my guests, I met the owner, Casey. Extremely nice man! In fact, he bought us a couple of shots to thank us for the business, and bringing new people to his bar. It's not the free drinks that make this awesome (although that sure was nice), it's the fact that he cares about his customers, and appreciates us bringing others. Just thought that was really cool, and will definitely cause me to keep coming back, and to keep bringing others.   So, you should go!! Oh, and did I mention everything inside is SOLID GOLD?!

2BbJnmvp55TYYjGuoG-S6w.review_text: 5 stars for cheap booze on the main drag of Fisherman's Wharf!  Live music and through-the-roof tacky factor.  But so much so, it's actually endearing.  Live music.  Friendly.  After a few, I thought I was in Vegas.

WDyILww9HxfTwq5zKOGymw.review_text: For the record, I'm a local, not a tourist.  I read all those articles that plastered the San Francisco Chronicle back when the Gold Dust Lounge was being forced to relocate from its former home on Union Square, and had promised myself that I would go check it out in its new location...and I have, several times previous to this particular occasion.  But after this last experience?  I won't be back.  As anyone who lives in a wheelchair or with some disability is all too well-aware, it is NEVER acceptable for someone to move your person or your mobility-assistance devices without your permission.  The latter, whether it's your wheelchair or scooter,  or a cane or oxygen tank, are to be considered as extensions of your body, or at the very least, your precious property.  This can also be dangerous for the person who requires said equipment in order to properly function, as able-bodied people often don't know any better and can damage your precious (and often expensive to repair) gear!  So imagine my horror when the manager and bouncer decided it was appropriate to start moving my motorized scooter without my consent!!  Because they didn't know how to operate it, they just brutally shoved at it, nevermind that it wasn't moving easily because the breaks were locked...the breaks that I'd just recently had repaired and didn't want to have broken again!!!  We asked them to stop, but the manager just waived his hand dismissively, told us it wasn't a big deal (IT WAS A BIG DEAL, IDIOT!!!!), and continued to aggressively shove my vehicle where he decided he wanted it to go, which meant that it was now blocking their ATM machine, ie, putting it directly in front of a destination for drunk people who will now need to awkwardly stumble over my scooter to use said ATM.  I was aghast.  These two jokers could have broken my breaks doing what they did, and that would've cost a LOT of money to fix, meant I'd have to be without my scooter for several days during which it was being repaired, and inconvenienced me terribly...all because they couldn't just politely ASK me to move it myself!  It could've also been a potentially dangerous situation:  I need those breaks to work because I live in San Francisco, and if y'all have noticed, there are a LOT of hills here!  Those breaks keep me from tumbling to my death!!  So because these two dolts decided it was more convenient for them to manhandle my gear than let me handle it, they put my life potentially in harm's way!!!  Maybe this sounds overly dramatic to you.  Let me assure you that it isn't.  My breaks went out almost a year ago on a hill, leaving my vehicle to roll backwards, gaining speed, until I intentionally stopped my fall by hitting a tree.  I was in pain for weeks afterwards, although I  was pretty lucky, considering how bad it could've been.  This is why it's so imperative that people respect my mobility device, and those owned by any other disabled person.  These gadgets aren't "fun" for us, they are our legs.  This is our LIVES.  After this occurred, I was so angry, I no longer wanted my drink.  My partner and I just left.  On the way out, I told off the bouncer, who, rather than apologize, just said, hey, it wasn't HIS fault, he was just obeying orders from the manager.  So I told him to tell the manager what I told him.    I doubt he did.  Safe to say, I won't be back here.  I don't feel respected or like my physical safety is cared about by this business.  Given all the other dive-y aspects of this touristy bar, I would much rather go somewhere where my safety, autonomy, and business is appreciated.  San Francisco is a BIG city, there are TONS of really great bars.  I'll be taking my business and that of my guests to one of them.

7kPR3NAhl72EGbUU1h9FOw.review_text: Great drinks, great prices, basically always happy-hour. Very good Irish coffee, very strong drinks.

76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg.review_text: Gold Dust is a solid old school style lounge to grab some cheap drinks at. The have $3.75 Happy Hour deals for Irish Coffee, Champagne, and Key Lime Margaritas- we only tried the Irish Coffee which was pretty good, although not as good as Buena Vista's. They also have a variety of scotches/whiskies/bourbons to choose from as well as a fully stocked bar, and plenty of beers on tap. The service can be a little slow if a lot of people are ordering at the same time, but the female bartender was really nice and helpful. They also have a live piano player on Thursday nights, which brings more of a jazzy vibe to the place.   If you're looking to grab a quick drink while in the Fisherman's Wharf area, definitely check out Gold Dust Lounge. There are stools available at the bar, and also booths against the wall. Make sure you check in on Yelp to get $1 off your 16 oz. draft beer! Parking is easy to find on the weekday nights, but can be difficult on the weekends.

H-sG9k0Xpv-rxQmJHpaxTg.review_text: Hey wait a second, this isn't a strip club!!!  I feel bamboozled!  Oh well a place that promotes binge drinking is a place I want to be.   Sign read 6 Jamesons for 15 bucks...oh hell yeah.    The bartenders and staff were super friendly and chill and with a huge bar with what looked like a runway behind the bar I expected to see some acrobatics going on back there, maybe a little Tom Cruise in Cocktail realness going on.   My peeps (Brad-lee & Melanio) and I only had a BloodyMary which I had a hard time drinking it down still nursing a hangover from the night before but I'm sure to come back when I'm in the area and do some damage to my liver.   Protip:  They have "Hookers" under the bar as well as outlets for getting your SmartPhone charged.

rTKK_-3W3gIQEohj0QSFWA.review_text: Located in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf you will find an unusual bar called the Gold Dust Lounge. The Gold Dust Lounge really seemed out of place next to souvenir shops and seafood restaurants however it quickly caught my attention when they advertised a Key Lime Margarita for only $3.75, and after a busy day I decided that this was the perfect place to stop for a quick drink to help refuel. The interior is surprisingly upscale with a casual feel yet it almost reminded me of an old school Vegas bar. As far as the service goes here it was great, the bartender was nice, and offered friendly conversation while we enjoyed the reasonably priced drink special. The Key Lime Margarita was pretty good, too.

XSidUIVewb5Csfo6Dn2N6Q.review_text: This is a great place for happy hour from 3-6p, several $3-3.50 drinks to choose from. Champagne,  beer, and a really good Irish coffee. On our trip to SF we went out of the way to make it here 3 times. Super friendly staff, relaxed vibe, and great decor.

v0ANF5-KxIWBtQQB0PfI4w.review_text: It's cleaner and brighter than the previous location but the bartenders still pour stiff drinks for a reasonable price.    I'll go back when they finish up the ceiling which is supposed to include the art and the smoke stains of the previous location.

gisZy0HKXvX4YMspboRmZQ.review_text: There's nothing golden about this place.   Came here a couple times at the new location, service has been indifferent at best.   It was definitely time to go when my manhattan came back shaken, with a nice piece of ice floating on top, with vermouth that tasted way past its prime.  It's one of your signature drinks. Come on.

4Xfeyf-yYN9MLx-jVW_5zg.review_text: I've been meaning to come here to the new location for the longest time especially now because the Clampers are going to be dedicating a plaque. But wow unfortunately it was NOT a very good experience for me, only reason I would return is if they fired the Bartender...  Not one to ask for someone to be unemployed but man you broke soo many rules it was not funny.   Let's start out with unsanitary, ok you want a nice looking hair do but when you constantly play with it and go back to touching the fruit for drinks that's gross. I'm sure that somebody told you that after you sneeze in your hand you DON'T wipe your hand on your side towel then start wiping down your glassware minutes afterwards... I was shocked didn't finish my drink but quickly got out of there...   Simply put great atmosphere and the place all around was really great I was very impressed but unfortunately for the bartender (asian tall guy, skinny jeans, converse and trying to have his hair spiked past his face) my experience was nothing good to write about...

jsxNHAaLcHkkd3QYG5xSzg.review_text: Oh Gold Dust, how I've missed you while you were gone!  So nice to be in a new and improved fancy version of the old place!  Gone is the smell of vomit, replaced with nice pretty bathrooms.  So much more space, perfect for relaxing and getting your drink on.  Best happy hours in town. GF & I sat there and watched some football, had some drinks, and enjoyed the heck out of the new digs.   Let's hope this location stays forever.   We'll always come back to the Gold Dust.

dO3AuXy1yIl-2ndWAGuahw.review_text: I miss the grime and ghost of Steve McQueen.

XMZtV131x-0JmVUVY6mEWA.user_location: North Beach/Telegraph Hill, San Francisco, CA
XMZtV131x-0JmVUVY6mEWA.review_text: Super nice decor with the classic look and feel with live music every night! Hard to find in SF. Margaritas, champagne, and Irish coffee happy hour menu all day/night!!  Mark and Mike, the owner and bar manager, are super nice, friendly, and professional. Our awesome server, Melissa is a sweetheart and always checked up on us to make sure we're ok. She is super attractive too.

0ZyrWHvkzndpyB2VtwI92A.review_text: Great dive bar style in a clean setting. Perfect place for a mid day drink or three!  The bar staff is funny, and has a real grasp on what they are doing. There are good drink specials and the selection itself is wonderful.  I liked it quite a bit. It takes you away from the cluster **** of the Fishermans Wharf crowd and gives you a nice place to take a drink break!
